'''Paula Todd''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[journalist]], lawyer and author, currently an investigative reporter for [[W5 (TV series)|W5]]. She was the founding host of ''"The Verdict with Paula Todd"''<ref name="theverdict">{{Cite news | url = http://media.ctv.ca/ctvnewsnet/releases/release.asp?id=9349&yyyy=2009 | title = The Verdict Is In. Paula Todd to Host Canadaâs First Crime and Legal Affairs News Series | publisher = [[CTV News]] | date = 12 March 2007 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref> a prime-time legal and justice affairs program on [[CTV News Channel (Canada)|CTV News Channel]]. Prior to joining [[CTV News]] in 2007, Todd was the host and co-producer of ''Person 2 Person with Paula Todd'', a [[TV Ontario]] interview program first broadcast in 2000. She had previously co-hosted the nightly, Gemini-award-winning [[newsmagazine]] [[Studio 2]] with [[Steve Paikin]] for 10 years before that show was cancelled in June 2006. Todd has written for numerous publications, including ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', the ''[[Toronto Star]]'', ''Elm Street Magazine'', ''[[Canadian Living]]'', and ''The Law Times''.
Todd earned her [[Bachelor of Arts]] in English literature from [[York University]]. She had served as co-editor of the University's student newspaper ''Excalibur'', a role she had initially "only wanted to get ... on her resume in order to beef it up for her application to law school"<ref name="Excalibur">{{Cite web | url = http://www.yorku.ca/ycom/profiles/past/mar00/current/features/article2_2.htm | title = Man Bites Dog | work = PROFILES | last = Chezzi | first = Derek
| publisher = Department of Communications, York University | date = March 2000 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref> She graduated with a [[Bachelor of Laws]] (LL.B.) from [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] in 1988.<ref name="YorkU">{{cite web | url = http://www.yorku.ca/ylife/2007/03-March/03-19/media.htm | title = Paula Todd hosts new show covering Black trial | work = Media | publisher = Ylife | date = 19 March 2007 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref> She was [[Call to the Bar|called to the Bar]] of the [[Law Society of Upper Canada]] in 1990.<ref name="calltotheBar">{{Cite journal | url = http://digital.olivesoftware.com/Olive/ODE/YorkU/LandingPage/LandingPage.aspx?href=WVJLLzIwMDcvMTAvMDE.&pageno=MjI.&entity=QXIwMjIwMA..&view=ZW50aXR5/th | title = In Paulaâs Court | work = YorkU | publisher = York University | date = 1 October 2007 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 | page = 22 }}</ref>
Todd entered broadcasting after more than a dozen years at Canadaâs largest newspaper, the [[Toronto Star]], where she worked as a reporter, feature writer and political correspondent. Throughout her last four years at the Toronto Star, she served as an editorial writer and a member of the newspaperâs editorial board.
Todd served as a judge for the [[National Newspaper Awards]], the Advancing Canadian Entrepreneurship (ACE) Awards and was nominated for a 'National Magazine Award' in 2003. She is the 2004 recipient of the Paramedic Associationâs Media Award for public education, and served on the Board of Directors of Integra, an organization that assists children and teens with learning disabilities, a cause she supports.<ref name="learning">{{cite news | url = http://www.prweb.com/releases/dyslexia/toronto/prweb2350484.htm | title = Paula Todd from CTV's W-FIVE Appearing at Toronto Dyslexia Conference | agency = PRWeb | publisher = Ontario Branch of the International Dyslexia Association | date = 23 April 2009 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref>
She is the author of the book ''A Quiet Courage: Inspiring Stories from All of Us'' (ISBN 978-0887621550), which was published in 2004. It was based on ''Person 2 Person''.<ref name="hometown">{{Cite web | url = http://www.yorku.ca/yfile/archive/index.asp?Article=3527 | title = Stories of hardship inspire author | work = Yfile | publisher = [[York University]] | date = 1 November 2004 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref>
A frequent contributor to radio and television before joining TVO, Todd was a regular host on [[CBC Newsworld]]'s 'Face Off', appeared as a frequent ''[[Global TV]]'' and ''CBC'' panelist, and also as a political analyst for [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] Radio in Toronto and Ottawa. Her contract with CTV News began on 1 March 2007.<ref name="CTVNews">{{cite web | url = http://www.yorku.ca/yfile/archive/index.asp?Article=7973 | title = Alumna Paula Todd joins CTV News | work = Yfile | publisher = York University | date = 26 February 2007 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref>
The debut episode of ''The Verdict'' was broadcast on 15 March 2007<ref name="firstair">{{Cite web | url = http://www.yorku.ca/yfile/archive/index.asp?Article=8110 | title = Todd hosts legal affairs show 'The Verdict' | work = Yfile | publisher = York University | date = 16 March 2007 | accessdate = 2010-05-31 }}</ref> from [[Chicago]], where the show was covering [[United States v. Conrad Black]], the criminal fraud trial of [[Conrad Black]].<ref name="YorkU" />
